docs.lead_paragraph: Since George E. Pataki became Governor three years ago, state lawmakers have engaged in a string of highly partisan fights over state budgets and emotional issues, like rent control, health care and welfare policy, that directly touched millions of people. But the 1998 legislative session, which begins Jan. 7 with the Governor's annual address to the Legislature, may pass without the rancor that has poisoned relations in the Capitol and produced three of the four latest budgets in state history. In separate interviews, Mr. Pataki, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, all agreed that for the first time in years, there is no explosive issue on the horizon and that budget negotiations could go smoothly.

headline.main: Leaders in Albany See a Relatively Calm Legislative Session

docs.abstract: New York State's 1998 legislative session, which begins Jan 7, may proceed without the rancor that has marked previous sessions and produced three of the four latest budgets in state history; in separate interviews, Gov George E Pataki, Senate majority leader Joseph L Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver all agree that for the first time in years there is no explosive issue on the horizon and that budget negotiations could go smoothly (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Pro-Government Gunmen Kill 45 Indian Refugees A band of pro-Government gunmen charged into a mountain hamlet in Mexico, spraying rifle fire and swinging machetes, killing 45 Indian refugees, Red Cross officials said. It was the bloodiest violence in the southern state of Chiapas since Indian rebels launched an uprising there nearly four years ago. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: This country's low-wage parents need government help in financing paid child care, despite David Blankenhorn's views (Op-Ed, Dec. 19). A single mother with two children needs a basic budget of about $11,000 to buy minimally decent food, shelter and transportation, according to the National Academy of Sciences. This doesn't include anything for child care or health insurance or taxes.

headline.main: Day-Care Subsidy Only Benefits Employed; Government Must Pay

docs.abstract: Prof Barbara R Bergmann letter points out that low-wage parents need help in paying for child care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After completing another phase of its extensive review of Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York region's largest managed-care companies, the New York State Insurance Department released a harsh critique of Oxford's management yesterday and fined the company $3 million for violating state insurance regulations. The department also ordered the company to refund roughly $500,000 to some customers. While the department did not call on Oxford to take any major new steps to remedy its problems paying doctors and tracking the cost of delivering care to its two million customers, the examination was notable for its critical tone.

headline.main: Oxford Health Receives Fine Of $3 Million

docs.abstract: New York State Insurance Dept, after completing another phase of its extensive review of Oxford Health Plans, releases harsh critique of Oxford's management and fines company $3 million for violating state insurance regulations; dept also orders company to refund roughly $500,000 to some customers; report describes 'poor planning and/or inexperienced management' as apparent cause of many of Oxford's difficulties and catalogues numerous regulatory infractions by company, including raising customers' premiums without sufficient notice, issuing contracts without approval of regulators and using unlicensed insurance agents to sell its products; Stephen F Wiggins, Oxford's founder and chairman, says Oxford has been cooperating with Insurance Dept for past two years, and 'is happy to get this report behind us, allowing us to move forward in the new year' (L)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans believe medical savings accounts are a sensible way to cut health insurance costs for the Government and private employers, to provide more affordable coverage for those who are uninsured and to help consumers save money. Democrats, though, see these accounts -- which involve tax-free savings and low-cost, high-deductible medical insurance -- as a tax break for the healthy and wealthy and a potential trap for unwary workers and some of the elderly.

headline.main: There's Been No Rush for Medical Savings Accounts, but Idea Is Gaining Favor

docs.abstract: First year of four-year pilot project on medical savings accounts has brought enrollment of far fewer people than Republican proponents had hoped; GAO report indicates sales may be increasing, although consumers are confused about complexity of new option; plan calls for consumers to purchase relatively inexpensive medical insurance that covers them fully for expensive illnesses but has very high deductible; part of money saved from premiums is placed in tax-free account which can accumulate year to year and may be used to meet uncovered medical expenses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law yesterday a measure that will provide free or subsidized health insurance starting next year to more than 100,000 children who have no coverage. Under the new law, $136 million in state and Federal aid will be used each year to enroll about 68,000 poor children in private managed-care plans. The law also raises income thresholds for Medicaid, making another 34,000 children eligible for coverage.

headline.main: Health Care Insurance Broadened for Children

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Whitman signs New Jersey law to provide free or subsidized health insurance to more than 100,000 children who have no coverage; photo; costs are shared with Federal Government (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE parents were in a state of shock upon hearing that their newborn baby had Down syndrome. But just as shocking as the news itself was the way the doctor delivered it: as a message on their voice mail. These parents, whose names were not disclosed, were among 182 families in Seattle and Minneapolis with chronically ill or disabled children who recently responded to a survey about insensitive remarks and other hurtful behavior they had encountered from doctors, nurses, friends and family members.

headline.main: Forget About Bedside Manners, Some Doctors Have No Manners

docs.abstract: Families in Seattle and Minneapolis with chronically ill or disabled children respond to recent survey about insensitive remarks and other hurtful behavior they had encountered from doctors, nurses, friends and family members; survey, part of continuing study of social support available to such parents, find that one-third of unsupportive experiences were with very people whose support was needed most: health care professionals, mainly doctors; survey echoes findings of other recent studies, as well as interviews with several doctors and parents, which show that for all the talk in recent years about improving communication between doctors and patients, doctors still have hard time breaking bad news, especially when patient is a child (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A dozen orphaned shoes, a legless dining room table, shopping bags of shattered china, a battered sewing machine: these are among the mangled remnants of Doreen Austin's life. Piled high to the ceiling in cartons, bags and tangled mounds, they envelop her like a cocoon but provide little comfort. A narrow passageway through the detritus connects her bedroom to the bathroom. The bathtub is filled with garbage bags of brightly colored fabric, raw material for a dress shop that might have been. ''Seeing this just breaks my heart,'' she said as the kitchen faucet dripped.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Nothing Left Except a Pile of Dreams

docs.abstract: Two charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund came to aid of Doreen Austin, 75-year-old woman who was brutally beaten during robbery, forced to stop work, and then lost her house when she fell behind on mortgage payments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: American International Group Inc., seeking to increase its sales to individuals in the United States and Latin America, said yesterday that it would purchase American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. for $2.2 billion. American Bankers, which in 1996 collected $2.5 billion in premiums and gave shareholders a 16.5 percent return, sells credit-related insurance. Its policies, sold through banks, retailers and other companies, cover loans for set periods in the event a borrower is disabled or dies. More than 8 percent of the 1996 premiums came from extended service contracts on electric appliances, a business AIG has already entered.
